name: 2,4-difluoro-3-methoxybenzoic acid
Reason:
To quantitatively predict the melting point of 2,4-difluoro-3-methoxybenzoic acid, we need to take into account the functional groups compared to a base molecule such as benzene. Benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. Functional groups will affect the melting point as follows:
- Fluoro substituents: +20°C each (due to the electronegativity and dipole interactions)
- Methoxy group: +30°C (it increases the molecular weight and volume, while the ether linkage can participate in dipole-dipole interactions)
- Carboxylic acid: +120°C (it can form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds, significantly increasing the melting point)
Cumulatively, the presence of two fluoro substituents adds 40°C, one methoxy group adds 30°C, and one carboxylic acid group adds 120°C to the base melting point of benzene.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. 
- Carboxylic acid group: +100°C (due to strong hydrogen bonding and dimerization). 
- Methoxy group: +10°C (due to the electron-donating effect and slight increase in molecular weight). 
- Fluoro groups: +20°C each (due to the strong electron-withdrawing nature and the increase in molecular weight). 
- The compound has two fluoro groups, so the total increase would be +40°C. 
- The presence of the methoxy group and the fluoro groups will also increase the melting point due to the rigidity and planarity of the molecule, which can lead to better packing in the solid state. This effect is not quantifiable but can be estimated to add another +10°C. 
##Prediction: 175.0
